supporting.text: January is the first month of the year in the Gregorian calendar, while March is the third month, making January precede March.

attacks.text: January is the first month of the year in the Gregorian calendar, while March is the third month, making January precede March.

supporting.text: The sequence of months in the Gregorian calendar is fixed, with January always followed by February and then March.

attacks.text: The sequence of months in the Gregorian calendar is fixed, with January always followed by February and then March.
Some cultures or calendars may not follow the Gregorian sequence, potentially placing March before January.
The Gregorian calendar is the internationally accepted civil calendar, making its sequence the standard reference.

supporting.text: In all standard calendar systems that include January and March, January is positioned earlier in the year than March.

attacks.text: In all standard calendar systems that include January and March, January is positioned earlier in the year than March.
Some non-standard or historical calendar systems may not include January or March, or may order them differently.
Non-standard calendar systems are irrelevant for the vast majority of practical purposes, and the claim implicitly refers to the Gregorian calendar.

supporting.text: Historical records and timekeeping practices consistently place January before March in annual chronological order.

attacks.text: Historical records and timekeeping practices consistently place January before March in annual chronological order.
Some ancient calendars, such as the Roman calendar before 153 BCE, did not have January as the first month of the year.
Modern Gregorian calendar, adopted worldwide, explicitly designates January as the first month, making historical exceptions irrelevant to contemporary usage.
In certain fiscal or academic calendars, the year may start in a different month, making January not universally the first month.
Even in fiscal or academic calendars, January still precedes March in the Gregorian sequence, which is the standard reference for month ordering.
